doc.title: Disappointing Q2 raises rating risks
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Disappointing Q2 raises rating risksDisappointing Q2 raises rating risks_2025-08-28

passages.text: Negative EBITDA due to inventory revaluation puts rating agencies' full- year estimates at risk, while leverage metrics have exceeded their downgrade thresholds. Bond valuations are rich, likely due to supportive market technicals. We reiterate our Underweight rating.

UPDATE This publication is an update to 'GS Caltex: Disappointing Q2 raises rating risks', originally published on 28 Aug 2025 at 07:46 SGT, to add important disclosures. There are no changes to the contents of the report.
- Underweight rating: Bonds valuations are rich, likely due to their short-dated maturities and generally supportive market technicals due to a lack of USD Asia bond supply.

- Disappointing earnings: 2Q25 EBITDA was negative KRW9bn due to inventory valuation losses as crude oil prices fell, and despite higher refining margins. The refining segment recorded losses as a result, while the petrochemical segment reported a modest earnings growth. The lubricants segment was the only segment where performance held up, with EBITDA rising 23% q/q, but fell 7% y/y.

- Rising downgrade risks: At the current run-rate, GS Caltex is likely to miss Moody's and S&P's full-year EBITDA estimate. The company's debt/EBITDA ratios have also exceeded both agencies' downgrade thresholds over the past 6-12 months. Rating risks are clearly rising at both agencies, in our view.

We maintain our Underweight rating due to valuations and its deteriorating credit profile, with growing risks to its ratings. However, we acknowledge that supportive technicals, due to the bonds' short- dated maturities and a general lack of USD Asia bond supply, will likely keep the GSCCOR spreads tight.

The GSCCOR 26s (z+17) are indicated at par as the bond will mature in four months in January 2026. We expect GS Caltex to refinance this bond, possibly in the KRW bond market, as we estimate that it is currently cheaper for the company to raise funds domestically.
The GSCCOR '28s (z+97) are marginally inside POSCO's (Market Weight, Baa1/A-/NR) higherrated POHANG '28s (z+100) and marginally wide of SK hynix's (Market Weight) HYUELE '28s

This document is intended for institutional investors and is not subject to all of the independence and disclosure standards applicable to debt research reports prepared for retail investors under U.S. FINRA Rule 2242. Barclays trades the securities covered in this report for its own account and on a discretionary basis on behalf of certain clients. Such trading interests may be contrary to the recommendations offered in this report.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 5. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 02:08 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 02:14 GMT Restricted - External
\((z + 94)\) , even though the issuer is rated mid- BBB but with a Positive Outlook from all three rating agencies.

At its current credit trajectory, we think GS Caltex should be viewed as a mid- BBB credit, and hence its bonds should be indicated \(\sim 10\) bp wide of the POSCO and SK hynix curves. In addition, the GSCCOR '28s are indicated almost 3pts above par, and hence there is room for valuations to fall if its ratings are downgraded.
Key positive risk to our view is the potential for the GS Caltex bonds to outperform its HG Korea Corporates peers in a weak market environment given its short- dated curve.
FIGURE 1. Korea HG Corporate scatter chart
Open in Barclays Live Chart  Source: Credit - Barclays Trading, S&P Global Market Intelligence
Earnings were disappointing in 2Q25, with the company reporting a negative EBITDA of KRW9bn. In comparison, GS Caltex reported KRW360bn of EBITDA in 1Q24 and KRW452bn in 2Q24.

Although refining margins rose \(q / q\) and \(y / y,\) lower crude oil prices led to inventory valuation losses. As a result, GS Caltex's refining segment recorded negative EBITDA of KRW166bn for the quarter, compared with a positive EBITDA of KRW249bn in 1Q25 and +KRW151bn in 2Q24.

Weakness in the petrochemical segment also weighed on performance, as segment EBITDA fell to KRW34bn, compared with KRW168bn in 2Q24, but higher \(q / q\) from KRW12bn in 1Q25. Spreads for aromatic products rose only marginally despite 2Q being a seasonally busy quarter historically, while the benzene spread over naphtha fell sharply, to USD151/t from USD217/t in 1Q25 and USD362/t in 2Q24 due to weak downstream demand. Olefin products fared better, although spreads also remained under pressure due to ongoing oversupply.
Lubricants held up relatively well, with KRW123bn of EBITDA \((- 7\%\) y/y, \(+23\%\) q/q). According to GS Caltex, this segment benefited from firm product prices and lower crude oil prices.
FIGURE 2. Segment EBITDA, KRW
Source: Company data, Barclays Research

We estimate negative free cash flow of KRW288bn in 2Q25, due to the weak operational performance and higher working capital needs. In particular, its trade payables balance fell by KRW674bn during the quarter, lowering its trade payable days to 17 from 22 in 1Q25.
Despite the negative free cash flow, net debt fell \(7\%\) q/q to KRW3.5trn, likely due to the USD depreciating by \(8\%\) against KRW during the quarter.
Nonetheless, credit metrics weakened, with its leverage ratios now exceeding Moody's and S&P's downgrade thresholds.

- LTM gross debt/EBITDA rose to 5.9x from 3.8x in the previous quarter. This ratio has exceeded Moody's adjusted debt/EBITDA > 3.5x downgrade threshold since 1Q25.- LTM net debt/EBITDA rose to 4.5x from 3.0x, and has exceeded S&P's adjusted debt/EBITDA > 2.0x downgrade threshold for a year, since 2Q24.

We also note that GS Caltex's LTM EBITDA of KRW777bn and 1H25 EBITDA of KRW351bn are significantly below the agencies' FY25 expectations of KRW1.6- 1.9trn in 2025- 26 (Moody's) and KRW1.8- 2.0trn (S&P). At its current run- rate, GS Caltex's full- year EBITDA is likely to fall short of the agencies' estimates.
Hence, we see rising risks that both agencies could reassess their ratings, or at least their Stable outlooks, in the coming months.
FIGURE 3. Rating triggers

GS CALTEX CORP, Underweight, CD/J
Valuation Methodology: Our UW rating is due to the bonds' tight valuations and a deteriorating credit profile, with growing risks to its ratings.

Risks that May Impede Achievement of the Rating: Key positive risk to our view is the potential for the GS Caltex bonds to outperform its Korea HG Corporate peers in a weak market environment given its short- dated curve.
Representative Bond: GSCCOR 5 3/8 08/07/28 (USD 102.74, 26- Aug- 2025)
POSCO, Market Weight, CD/J

Valuation Methodology: Following recent underperformance, the POHANG bonds are now moderately cheap compared with their Korea HG Corporate and metals/mining peers. However, the absence of positive catalysts, a still- sluggish but recovering steel sector, and our expectations of an S&P downgrade, keep us from being more constructive on the credit.

Risks that May Impede Achievement of the Rating: Positively, the POHANG bonds could outperform its peers if there is increased optimism that that China's steel over- capacity is reduced and steel profitability will rise. This could drive better- than- expected 2025 earnings and a material improvement to its credit metrics.
Negatively, persistent weakness in steel margins would weigh on POSCO's profitability and credit metrics. Bonds could also underperform if S&P downgrades its ratings in the coming months.
Representative Bond: POHANG 5 3/4 01/17/28 (USD 103.15, 27-Aug-2025)
SK HYNIX INC, Market Weight, CD/J

Valuation Methodology: The company's credit profile will likely continue to improve. However, we see limited room for spreads to compress from current levels. At the same time, uncertainties arising from US trade policies, including potential tariffs, could weigh on bond performance in 2H25.

Risks that May Impede Achievement of the Rating: Positively, we believe the HYUELE can outperform its peers if potential US tariffs on semiconductors are milder than feared, while SK hynix sustains its strong earnings momentum.
Negatively, potentially punitive US tariffs on semiconductors could weigh on credit spreads as it raises concerns over the likely impact on SK hynix's future earnings.
Representative Bond: HYUELE 6 1/2 01/17/33 (USD 109.29, 27-Aug-2025)

All pricing information is indicative only. Unless otherwise indicated, prices are sourced from LSEG Data & Analytics and reflect the closing price in the relevant trading market, which may not be the last available price at the time of publication.

Sectors in U.S. High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield \(2\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield \(2\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index.
Sectors in European High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index.

Sectors in Industrials and Utilities in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield \(3\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield \(3\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials.

Sectors in Financials in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index.

Sectors in Asia High Grade Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index. Sectors in Asia High Yield Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index.

Sectors in EEMEA and Latin America Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index. These sectors may contain both High Grade and High Yield issuers.
